Harbor Route and Related Proposals



expressway which would branch off to the north onto Broadway
from the Northern Route of the East-West Expressway. This
branch, known as the Broadway Radial, would continue north
along Broadway, crossing under North Avenue, and would then
swing around to merge with a widened Harford Road just above
the present intersection of Harford Road and Broadway.

While this proposal would seem to offer a good connection to
the northeast it also poses certain problems. As planned it would
be expensive to construct and the problem has been complicated
in the last few years by the installation of a new major sewer line
in Broadway. Furthermore, it is probable that during rush hours
the Northern Route would be operating close to capacity so that
there might be inadequate spare capacity to absorb any large
amount of traffic coming in on the Broadway Radial from the
northeast. The Broadway Radial does not now appear feasible.

In exploring the possibilities of additional proposals to serve
the northeast, these factors stand out:

a. No new facilities are possible without some demolition of

residential properties.

b. The only section of the Jones Falls Expressway from
which a branch expressway could take off to serve the
northeast is that portion near Chase Street currently
reserved for the interchange with the East-West Express-
way. If the East-West Expressway were transferred to
the Harbor Route this stretch would become available for
a branch to the northeast.

c. It would appear that some advantage ought to be taken
of the possibility of widening Hoffman Street between
Greenmount Avenue and Bond Street by utilizing the

44

strip of cleared land to the south over the Pennsylvania
Railroad tunnel.

d. Harford Road opposite Clifton Park occupies a strategic
location since a number of main roads to the northeast
converge here—Loch Raven Boulevard, The Alameda,
Hillen Road, and Harford Road itself. The City is
already proceeding with plans to widen this stretch of
Harford Road.

Putting these factors together suggests a possible new solu-
tion which is illustrated on Sheets 31 through 34. Under this
proposal Harford Road would be made one way south from North
Avenue to Hoffman Street and, if necessary, from North Avenue
to 25th Street. Southbound traffic would continue down Harford
Road, swing west on a widened Hoffman Street, proceed over
Greenmount Avenue and the railroad tracks on an elevated struc-
ture, and join the Jones Falls Expressway at about Eager Street.

Northbound traffic would follow a similar route in reverse up
to the intersection of Harford Road and Hoffman Street. At this
point northbound traffic would continue straight ahead on Hoff-
man Street to Bond Street. There are several possibilities for
connecting this point with Harford Road north of North Avenue.
Two of these are illustrated. One would provide an elevated
structure to carry the northbound traffic over the railroad tracks
onto Broadway. It would then proceed on the surface across
North Avenue, cut across the western end of Holy Cross Cemetery
and proceed to Harford Road. Another possibility would carry
northbound traffic over Broadway and the railroad tracks to join
Rutland Avenue. Rutland Avenue would then be extended across
North Avenue and the eastern end of Holy Cross Cemetery, swing
